prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Main Science Goal
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will infer the gas masses and distributions for a sample of star forming galaxies at z~1 with continuum observations of the optically thin part of the Rayliegh Jeans tail and assuming a gas to dust mass ratio.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
See also the main proposal text.
By combining the star-formation rates (SFRs 5-15 Msol/yr), the spatial extent of the galaxies and the `global' Kennicutt-Schmidt relation from Genzel et al.(2010) we estimate the intrinsic gas masses for our galaxies should be 0.6-2e10Msol (corresponding to a gas fraction of 40-70% in all cases for our sample, Stott et al. in prep).
The observations will target the optically thin Rayleigh Jeans tail of the dust emission from which we infer gas masses via the gas-to-dust ratio (Scoville et al. 2013). We note that our galaxies are all near solar abundance (from [NII]/Halpha ratio, Stott et al. in prep and Stott et al. 2014) and have high stellar masses (>1e10Msol) therefore the Scoville et al. (2013) gas-to-dust formulae apply. In Fig 2. we calculate the Band 7 continuum flux corresponding to gas masses of 0.25-2e10Msol utilising the equations of Scoville et al. (2013). Using the ALMA observing tool, integration time calculator we find that in a ten minute, on target, Band 7 observation we can probe down to an inferred gas mass of 0.6e10Msol to a significance of 5 sigma (flux=0.3mJy) and 0.4eMsol to 3 sigma. For the large, gas rich members of our sample this means we can easily probe the distribution of gas at our requested resolution of 0.4'' (3 kpc). With overheads and calibrations this adds up to a total time of 6.6 hours.
As our targets all fall in the same field on the sky we can use the same calibrations for all which keeps our total progamme length to a minimum.
Our field is observable from October onwards and therefore avoids the Band 7 restrictions in December to February discussed in the Call for Proposals.
We are using Band 7 as the execution times are quicker than Band 6 and the overheads are less than Bands 8 and 9
We are performing continuum observations so spectral resolution is not applicable.

The resolution of 0.4'' corresponds to 3 kpc at this redshift, which is the scale of the best seeing conditions we have for our ground based KMOS data and thus we should be able to resolve the same structure.
Gas on angular scales of up to ~20kpc may exist in these galaxies so we set the largest angular scale value to 3''

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
It is vital to our understanding of galaxy formation and evolution to determine if the prescriptions for star formation, such as the Kennicutt-Schmidt law, are applicable to the rapidly evolving inter stellar medium of gas-rich, high-redshift galaxies. To test this, spatially resolved observations of both the star formation and the cold gas that fuels it, for typical high redshift star forming galaxies, are required. We propose to measure the cold molecular gas masses for 25 z~1.0 star forming galaxies for which we possess spatially resolved Halpha derived star formation rates and dynamics from our ongoing VLT KMOS programme KROSS.
We will infer the gas masses for our sample (via gas-to-dust ratios) with ALMA Band 7 continuum observations of the dust emission from the optically thin region of the Rayleigh Jeans tail. This approach does not rely on the uncertain conversion from CO gas mass to molecular Hydrogen. The other great advantage of this method is that we only require 10 minute integrations per galaxy to derive typical gas masses, which is significantly less than the >1 hour required to obtain this measurement from CO line emission.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: PROPOSAL CODE: 2013.1.01239.S PROPOSAL TITLE: Probing the z=1.0 Kennicutt-Schmidt law by combining ALMA and VLT KMOS observations P.I.: John Stott This has not (yet) been observed in Cycle 2 but was ranked in the 10-20% band of all submitted proposals and assigned priority grade B. This was to use ALMA to study the gas content of the first 11 KMOS observed galaxies that met our criteria (from our KMOS Science Verification programme in the SA22 field). This new proposal is complementary and draws on our expanded number of KMOS observed targets, this time in the ECDFS field.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
